caption: This museum is the best place to know about the immigration history of France. You gain so much how France has changed and evolved and revolutionized over the years and has welcomed every race and ethnicity.

A newly renovated museum with an interesting story. The building is interesting to look around and you can visit the big main room for free. There is a cafe and cloak room. A lot of the actual museum mostly had writing on the walls with some objects and a couple of videos. Because of this I don’t think it’s very interesting for young children. The information on big panels is translated to English and the smaller panels just in french. There’s a music room where you can listen to playlists and relax part way through your visit. The museums follows the history of immigration in France all the way up to the present day. Underneath the museum there is a tropical aquarium. I went on a weekday in summer and it wasn’t busy.

The temporary Olympics exhibition was amazing! It has great history presented in an easy to read format in both English and French. I learned a lot and enjoyed the short trip out here from the 11th arr.

Staff was a bit unfriendly and we were kicked out of multiple areas of the museum because they were setting up for something else. Hard to find entrance too. Temporary exhibit was very interesting.  Aquarium is a nice place to visit, however. A bit dark as it’s underground but fun for the kids.

I visited the museum with a friend and we loved the exhibition ("Paris et nulle part ailleurs") as well as the building itself. Especially in the evening, its exterior was such a pelasure for the eyes.

Rich, criative and colourful. Spacious, elegant. It is relatively small but rich, dense collection of facts, figures, pictures and artifacts telling tales of immigration in France. Tres fantastique! No big queues, ok price €6.50 inclusive an exhibition. Almost empty when I visited in contrast to other pop museums.
Recomendable for french and for people born in the old french colonies. Not for foreigners or tourists, because they are very focused in their own history.

A great museum, with a range of different exhibitions to go and see. The main exhibition, which I went to, was great - I particularly liked the ‘un langue universel’ part, with great colours and shapes.

I loved the architecture and building but disappointed by lack of facilities like having to ask Security to use a lift if you cannot manage stairs.  It was too noisy with groups of teenagers with guides and difficult to navigate around them so prolonging my time as I had to move on and go back when they had moved on.  I think these groups should have special times allocated just for them, not same time as general public.  It was an interesting and informative museum for the price.
The building is beautiful. The permanent exposition is big but it is not interactive and the information is too dense to really learn something.

A highly disappointing visit. This museum has managed to take the most interesting subject of history, and convert it into the most boring museum visit I have ever had in my life. Most of the museum feels like reading a middle school history textbook.  Furthermore, the cafe serves excruciatingly disgusting coffee, and food.  Apart from an impressive building, this museum, sadly, has nothing to offer except disappointment of great proportions.
This is a good museum about the history of migration to France. The irony is that being about migration almost all is in France. My family and I enjoyed it and learned a lot about people on the move.

Impressive, interesting and very French. Great place to visit for the exposition, but don’t expect to be informed if you don’t speak French. The hall is very impressive. Keep your nose closed in the bathroom!

A great museum, full of facts and documents.  It's nice that a so long story is supported with more typical history documents but also with photos and newspapers, even journals used to despise the immigrants, but they give the visitors a lively picture of the hard facts.
Nice and informative museum. It's not so interactive and there is lots of written information but in general, I recommend going, especially since the topic is interesting.

Unique and very interesting museum focused on French immigration policy and social integration of global groups.  Well attended by French locals and a key add-on to the child happy aquarium in the basement space.  We enjoyed our visit: planning for a quick 20 minute review, we stayed 2 hours and delighted in the time here, well spent.
The museum had so many awesome facts and the aquarium is excellent for kids!

What a wonderful surprise this museum was. Although my children do not speak French, there were English translations throughout the museum to make it more than worthwhile. There are special shows every 30 minutes that are only in French unfortunately, but there are some that are more animated and action packed, making the language barrier less important. Go early because the planetarium sells out. An excellent rainy day activity for kids!

We went on the first Sunday of the month when visits are free. The temporary exhibition was about music (and immigration) and was really well-made and informative. The building is just beautiful by itself and worth seeing. The place has plenty of stories waiting to be discovered

Disappointing museum. The temporary exhibit was interesting but the permanent displays lack structure and depth. It's just random stuff with lots of posters and news clippings. And why is there nothing about food as that is a huge impact that immigrants have had - there is a Chinese, kebab, or pizza etc. place every 100 meters here in Paris and it's a super important element of culture.
Want to know about Immigration history of France? Must visit then. They have Amazing guides to walk through the museum.
Beautiful, open, sunny and friendly museum. The exhibits are always worth going to and the aquarium is fun, affordable and great for kids.

The temporary exhibition about immigration was really worthing it (it was frontières at that time), otherwise the exhibition is not interactive enough,  with a lots of reading. The place art déco style is nice,  but the  coffee place inside was not opened on Sunday
A great place. Be8ng an imm8grant I cried while visiting..... my ancient already went all over the world.....

Cool, but in kasse dont understand what you want. I say tiket in museum and aquarium, finally me give only in aquarium.   7 eur in aquarium. When i buy in museum and aquarium it was 10 eur.  Shame, in museum dont can go :( 7 eur  to aquarium i diferent 7 eur for museum to me is to big
There is nothing just a bad version low cost low time testimonial of one or two marocain emigrant, with some photos that doesn't represent neither the country neither their people
Interesting place, but most information text is only in French. There are some English and German but you can get by as the displays are interesting.
Worth a visit
Great museum in a beautiful historical building - almost no English translations though so bring a phone equipped with google translate
The beat museum in Paris!
- beautiful art deco building - very good permanent and temporary exhibits, providing you are interrested in social history
A very important place to visit while in Paris
National museum is a big histor of the world....
Museum will be interesting only for francophones. Expositions would have sens to see online.
To little information in English. But a very cool museum and the displays  with photos and videos are well done.
It is interesting in the way it presents the information to the public but there is no rich collection at all
Terrible staff, rude with the clients. They didn’t want to give as tickets in at the start and started to give to others, they lied that they don’t have places, Don’t recommend
Very impressive museum and exhibition, really recommend this place
